title: Why Sir David Attenborough won't let crews save animals on Seven Worlds, One Planet

From grey-headed albatross parents nuzzling their fluffy newborn chicks adoringly in South Georgia to stunning Iberian lynxes prowling through the forests of Spain... the incredible diversity of wildlife across our planet’s continents never ceases to fill Sir David Attenborough with delight.

Despite almost 70 years as a natural history presenter, he still possesses a childlike wonder when describing the spectacular scenes in this epic series.

Each of the seven episodes tells the story of one continent, celebrating its unique characteristics, iconic landscapes and, most of all, the amazing creatures there.

(Image: Getty Images)

It’s a wondrous world tour that’ll delight fans of Planet Earth and Blue Planet, with incredible footage of weird and wonderful animals in nerve-shredding moments of life-or-death jeopardy.

Sir David tells us about Earth’s extraordinary diversity and picks out his personal highlights from a show painstakingly put together over four years...

(Image: BBC Studios/Emma Napper)

Australia

The giant 6ft tall cassowary lurks in jungles and is one of the world’s most dangerous birds – with claws longer than a velociraptor dinosaur’s.

Asia

'This is one of the stars of the series,’ David explains.

‘There’s a wonderful creature called a golden-haired, blue-faced snub-nosed snow monkey.

Their noses are like that to stop them getting frostbite.’

(Image: BBC Studios/Nick Green)

Europe

‘This is a continent transformed by humanity,’ says David.

‘We’re changing the world so rapidly, wildlife is facing some of its greatest challenges yet.’

North America

In South Dakota, cute prairie dogs have a complex means of communication that’s even better than that of dolphins and chimpanzees .

(Image: BBC Studios/Maddie Close)

Africa

While making the show, we can’t interfere with a cheetah stalking an antelope as it’s a complicated situation,’ stresses Sir David.

‘You’re likely to cause more trouble than just letting nature take its course.

Baby cheetahs need food too.’

(Image: Getty Images/Gallo Images ROOTS)

Antarctica

'It’s the harshest continent of them all,’ says Sir David.

‘Weddell seal pups leave the warmth of their mother’s womb, at 37ºC, and fall straight on to the ice – it’s the sharpest drop in temperature any newborn animal faces in the world.’

(Image: BBC Studios/John Brown)

South America

The riches of South America are full of the unexpected,’ says Sir David.

‘These Guanacos in Chile learn to walk within five minutes of being born.’

(Image: Chadden Hunter/BBC Studios)

Did you know?

About 200million years ago our world looked very different, with just one super-continent called Pangaea surrounded by vast expanses of ocean.

When it broke apart, life on Earth was cast adrift on fragments of land which eventually became the seven major land masses we know today.

Seven Worlds, One Planet is on Sun 6.15pm BBC One
description: Join natural history legend Sir David Attenborough as he takes us on a magical journey to each of the continents of our wonderful world
